comments.commentBody: What future generations?
They will laugh at the parasitic gambling industry with its capital city in the bleakest of deserts.

What future generations will marvel at and laugh at is the current obsession with the fantasy we call climate change.  Much like the current generation laughs at what in the 70's was the concern over global cooling.

Fun entries? There could have been many, many more theme entries starting with one of those four words.

RegEx Mode: 1,145 results for regular expression ^((FULL)|(ACTION)|(STICK)|(GO)).{8,13}$

The entries that were the most fun for me weren't theme entries.

The flavor was great on this, especially if you don't have the time to marinade in advanc. I used slightly more olive oil and vinegar than the recipe called for, so the rub was extra pasty. But even after 3 hours for a 3 pound bone-in pork butt, the meat never became tender enough to fall apart. It sliced much more like a short-cooking pork loin. That was a bit of a disappointment.
Kiki, I guessed wrong, too.

These are the end of times for the Republican party as we knew it. Trump and Cruz each represent "unelectable" factions of the party, that cumulatively are the majority of Republicans, but can never be reconciled. The party has three major factions now; and only inchoate anger unites them.

Having the partly leadership openly and blatantly refusing to consider Obama's appointment would be the mark of political idiocy in any ordinary time -- instead the party leaders would mumble meaningless pieties, slow-walk everything, reject a candidate ... and Obama's time would run out. No crisis or posturing or immediate damage to centrist Republicans.

Instead the party is provoking a crisis solely because most Republicans are too scared of their own voters, who are demanding the unlikely or even impossible, to do the rational thing.

With Trump and Cruz the leading Republicans the chances of a Republican president are vanishing as the days go by. No sane political observer expects either of them to be able to win, even against Sanders.

Logically seeing the disaster that is the presidential campaign, the Republicans would do everything they can to attempt to hold onto the senate and maintain a large majority in the house.

But Scalia's death has provoked them into a foolish tantrum. And it looks like another one may be not too far away: Paul Ryan getting "Boehnered."

The Republicans are dissolving into a circular firing squad.

The Stockholm plowed into the Andrea Doria; people died.

Thank you, Robert, for the link to the Andrea Doria.  Reading the description of the maneuvers leading up to the collision with the Stockholm brought back memories of tense moments on nighttime bridge watches during my service in a Navy destroyer a few years earlier.  A closing rate of almost forty knots does not give much time for choosing the correct action for avoiding a collision.

9:10 pm PST-

I suppose all that transcendental party-ing compensated for all the dead babies. And we, in our hollow and superficial lives, are poorly compensated by being able to produce our young without fear for the life of the mother and with every expectation of our children being healthy.

"The beagle, he said, is 'a nose with four feet attached.' "

The beagles in my household have turned up their noses and refuse to dignify that comment with the slightest feign of a sniff.

It is a joy to watch people who have fallen into just the right place. Best wishes for the Philadelphia show.

I have no idea what will become of humanity.

We may not wage physical wars against each other as often as in the past
but we do wage economic wars where the victor has more riches
than they know what to do with and the defeated become economic
wage slaves.

If I had to guess I would say that when the next great plague sweeps through
the world, the rich will enclose themselves in their private and sanitised villas an the rest of us will be left to die. The few of us that happen to have a
natural immunity may survive to become servants of the rich who ignored
all those who died.

Add in those nations that have nuclear weapons and seem eager to try them
out on their enemies...

No, we are not getting better for our potential for evil has never been greater.

I have felt since the Senate went pro-Constitution in 2014 that it could easily go back to the anti party this fall. Eight trillion dollars' worth of freebies and giveaways should have bought the Democrats more than enough votes to unseat 5 religious patriots.

However, if Flipper Trump takes the White House, only a couple of issues can be counted on by the Right to go their way, and the economy definitely is not one of them.

For a second I misread our writer Cohn's last word to start with an S.
I'm still trying to figure out how to spell your name.

We hung ourselves when Medicare came through and doctors have seen almost annual fee reductions for services, to the point that the lose money on these paperwork-heavy oldsters.

Go check out the 1965 estimates for Medicare spending in the years ahead, such as 1990.

The median annual Certified Nurse Anesthetist salary is $168,721 as of 1/31/16.

The median annual Physician Anesthesiologist salary is $352,686 as of 1/31/16.

How will she "earn nearly as much as an MD anesthesiologist"?

I don't have current figures for the student loan debt to income ratio for either group, but some time back there was an article pointing out that, while nursing education costs a lot less than that for a physician, the ratio of debt to income was actually higher for a nurse than for a physician. That obviously varies with specialties and various other factors, and it's possible it's no longer true, but simply stating that she'll have less debt doesn't mean a whole lot without more information.
Now compare the out-of-pocket for each group for liability insurance. It can double in a month for doctors.

I am in a surgical specialty with 35 years in practice. Last week I saw in my office a young lady, a college student. I asked her what her career goal was. and she replied, "certified registered nurse anesthetist." Such a well-defined goal at such a young age is unprecedented in my experience, but it made perfect sense. Interested in medicine, she had followed doctors around in the hospital and their offices, and every one had advised her not to go to medical school. She grew up on a ranch and is unusually mature with a highly developed sense of responsibility. She will graduate with a nursing degree, spend a year or two as a clinical nurse, earning at least as much as a resident after four years of medical school, then go on to nurse anesthesia school for another two years. She will earn nearly as much as an MD anesthesiologist, not have a huge debt, and have less malpractice risk because she will not be doing the risky cases. Most of all, she will have a life outside of medicine.
Daniel Allan, MD, FACS

For all your Rhetoric, the Democratic establishment can produce only one candidate for President, an old white woman with all the same street cred of trump boast of. unfortunately, Bernie makes it look like she is in a race.

The right wing's political philosophy is: This is our country. We are the boss.

And of course the boss is not black or brown, female, gay etc., poor, or work for him. Cops and military are the strong arm that keeps the ruling coterie in power. Trump says he knows all the big shots in corporations, banks, and government. It's a club you and I do not belong to. They had one of theirs in a Supreme Court Justice chair deciding in their favor. The fly in the ointment in American politics is that the voters have to vote. They don't have to know anything or live in anything other than a brilliantly choreographed media fantasy. But they have to vote. So there is this multi-billionaire-dollar persuasion industry whose job it is to manipulate the masses into voting for the fascists' guys. So keeping the fascist seat without losing control of the mindless mass is a delicate matter.

Breastfeeding is a demand thing:  the more you nurse, the more milk you have.  If you use supplemental bottles in the beginning you never develop enough supply as your baby grows and that is why so many mothers stop nursing at about 3 months which is when baby often has their first really big growth spurt.

What's better - some breastmilk, or no breastmilk? If you fail to take into account that the majority of mothers combo feed to some extent, and instead push unrealistic goals like "exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months," then you may very well end up with less breastfeeding altogether. For many women, it's literally impossible to pump enough when they go back to work, so supplementation is a given. For other women (many more than people think), they just never make enough milk for the baby to thrive. Milk production is far from perfect, and forget about it once the mother returns to work.

Also, supplementing with formula in the first week for babies that have lost weight has been shown to actually increase breastfeeding rates overall.

Jennifer--It's true that the body adapts, but I had no problem at all nursing after work and at night and in the morning.  My supply was just fine at those times, and after three months at home with each infant, I was able to keep that pattern up.

Most of what I've read on each side of this issue is pretty dogmatic.  This article makes a small mention of an option that might be considered more often to the benefit of babies and their moms.  You can nurse your baby when you are with the baby, and when someone else must do the feeding that person can use formula.  This eliminates the need for pumping for those who don't have the time or space to do it.  Back in the '80's, when my kids were born, the available breast pumps were pathetic, there was no place at work to pump, and help was nonexistant.  So when I went back to work after three months I weaned them during the daytime and nursed them in the afternoon, evening, and morning.  putting this out there as an option might keep families breast feeding longer than many now do, still getting its benefit at half of their feedings.  I literally never hear this mentioned.
Where is Martin? Hopefully not in an El Paso resort.

You may disagree but what evidence do you have of this position?  On almost every measure other than the pessimism people carry within - humanity IS getting better.  One of the major reasons it appears not, is that we have become so good at reporting and making people aware of our failings, that people are biased towards those failings.  This phenomenon is well known as availability bias.

I commend the good professor for his most optimistic read on the species and it's foibles over the last 200,000 years.  But I disagree and I give him in response the words of the American author William Faulkner when writing about the belief that we have time.  A father giving his son a watch said "I give you the mausoleum of all hope and desire; it’s rather excruciatingly apt that you will use it to gain the reducto absurdum of all human experience...The field only reveals to man his own folly and despair, and victory is an illusion of philosophers and fools."  Two hundred millennia we've spent on this pale blue dot and we've only become better at our self-eradication.  A good philosopher should by now know that "out of the crooked timber of humanity nothing straight was ever made." It's not hopelessness I'm arguing for but a cruel truth about knowing the future and the core principle of induction in science:  Sustained past performance is indeed an indication of future outcomes. And the record of the past in sum (200K years) is not good.  Just because we’ve played with the scientific method in the last 500 years doesn’t assure me that we won’t regress to what we were in the first 199,500 years of our existence. Progress is not what we’ve been good at since we evolved to homo sapiens. In a long horse race even an old nag has a short burst in speed, before she returns to a feeble trot and keels over with no finish in sight. Ergo, I wouldn't bet so hopefully on our number.

"Today, pestilence threatens us not because of our ignorance but because of the success of our systems." Actually, this is part of the myth of progress. Black Death traveled the silk road from Asia. And epidemics still flourish not only due to travel, but also due to the ignorance of our systems, as we saw with Ebola last year.

Overall things are getting better for humanity. There still is a lot of work to be done but as technology improves so does the quality of life for everyone. The continuous story of chaos, crisis, and drama in the news reports keeps media organizations busy and the conversation lively. Everything is better and wonderful in the world just doesn't get the kind of play as horror and tragedy does that angers and shocks people.

This recipe started out very promising. Then I added the chicken. Turns out three pounds of chicken is a LOT of chicken. Still cooking but I'm concerned my wonderfully spicy smelling dish will end up being a morass of chicken meat. Will probably cut the amount of chicken in half for subsequent attempts.
